characters: IN 1970 THERE WERE 300,000 ADDICTS IN THE U.S. YESTERDAY,
THE SCREEN GOES BLACK. A TITLE APPEARS

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: BOBBY SEALE -- a skinny, kinetic black man sporting an Af teeters on a chair in front of a small CROWD. He reads fr a crumpled sheaf of papers. At the side of the crowd, HUEY NEWTON -- well-built, magn watches, grooving on the rhythm of the words.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Yeah it's easy to see right on your black and white TV. Black man. Blue cop. Red blood. Niggers watch other niggers die. That's right Niggers watching niggers die. That's the American way... A COMMOTION starts at the rear of the crowd. TWO UNIFORME COPS roughly make their way to Bobby. They pull him off h chair, cracking his head against the ground. The cop over Bobby raises his NIGHTSTICK... A BLACK HAND grabs the club, stopping its arc. Shocked, the cop turns. It's HUEY. With honed precision, DECKS the cop with his free hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruised and bloody, Huey and Bobby sit next to each other the car moves through the streets.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (over) Pigs threw them in jail. There they starting talking about black folks oughta start standing up. No master plan, no pot to piss in, nothing like that. Just two fed-up brothers... Next thing you know, you got the Black Panther Party for Self Defense...

dialogues.speaker: BLACKOUT
dialogues.text: Again, the SCREEN goes BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (over) For me, it started different. A lot different. You may as well say The Panthers started in my front yard... The black screen DISSOLVES into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONCRETE, cracked and dirty, fills the frame. A BICYCLE w past, gliding down the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Teeming with life on a bright day, the Ghetto moves to it own unique cadence. A YOUNG BOY, no older than ten, pedal down the street on his BICYCLE. A gust of wind brushes a SHAPELY WOMAN. She GRABS a HAT a holds tight, ignoring her DRESS rising in the wind. The B ogles her juicy thighs.

dialogues.speaker: SHAPELY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Shucks I see you staring, but I ain't letting go. Them hips is almost forty years old but the hat is brand new! AFRAID, the boy PASSES an OAKLAND POLICE CAR, cruising sl down Market. A WHITE COP scans the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continuing his ride, the BOY passes TYRONE (20's) -- a TO YOUTH -- who GLARES at the cop car, LEAFLETS in his HANDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK HANDS pour a CAN of LEMON JUICE into a BOTTLE of ch WHITE PORT. Shaking the mixture, then swigging it, ROSE ( an aimless drunk -- passes it to his FRIENDS.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Yes indeed, that Bitter Dog... (to the Boy) What's up little brother? Smiling, the YOUNG BOY waves to the sidewalk drinkers, th moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes downcast, the BOY passes REVEREND SLOCUM (50's) -- a passionate preacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the street corner, SABU (20's) -- a Superfly young hus with a fast mouth -- trying to sell cigarette lighters to couple of HARD HATS heading off to work.

dialogues.speaker: SABU
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, man. The perfect gift for the sophisticated lady in your life. Light up her flame with some solid gold satisfaction and get a second one half price for your wife. Can't beat my price with a stick, baby. CY, a large man with an eye-patch, walks up and tries, in vain, to get one of Sabu's bogus lighters to light. cy Sabu, why're you still tryin’ to sell these raggedy ass, non workin! Korean lighters man? The HARD HATS drive off laughing as Sabu curses CY out. T boy continues on heading for the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly a HORN blares, BRAKES screech. Brutal, fast, a CAR plows into the child, sending him and the bike bouncing against the windshield and back on the pavement, bleeding... dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDGE (20's) -- an intense young man wearing a FATIGUE JA STARES numbly at the child in the street. Neighborhood pe move toward the scene. A WOMAN, perhaps the boy's mother, WAILS next to the body Judge's Mom, RITA (50's) -- raw boned and sharp eyed -- stands, drawn toward the tragedy.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Oh lord... not again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CROWD -- including Reverend Slocum, Cy and the DRINKERS gathers near the child and the wailing woman. Across from Judge, TYRONE keeps an angry distance from the horror. cy God damn... Kid never had a chance...

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Mothafuck... Hey!!! What the hell!!! The CAR backs up, trying to leave the scene. Market street regulars SWARM around the retreating vehicl hitting it with fists, sticks, bottles. Young and old mov together, their faces contorted with RAGE.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (over) People were pissed off. Neighborhood had been begging for a stoplight since before dirt was invented. Way I saw it then, that boy dying was another shitty thing in a world full of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes locked on the dead child, JUDGE stands, angry and impassive.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (over) Way I see it now... That day. That intersection. That's where it started for me. (a pause) Only, I didn't know it then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Running red past a SMALL sneakered foot, BLOOD streams to the gutter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BASKETBALL bounces off the cement, SNEAKERED FEET scram past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDGE drives in for a basket, pursued by CY. It's a frien three on three street game. The MARKET STREET DRINKERS - including ROSE -- fill out Cy and Judge's teams. Young neighborhood MEN watch the game and shoot the shit. One of them, JAMAL, sports a beard and a DASHIKI. Somewhere a RADIO plays James Brown's "Say it Loud"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gliding around Cy, Judge sinks a basket. ROSE retrieves t ball.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: You supposed to be a wounded vet, Motherfucka. What you do in 'Nam anyway, shoot gooks or shoot hoops?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: All of the above, man... (a pause) And then some. Shaking off the memory, Judge takes the ball in, PASSING to a teammate. The BALL arcs through the air...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANDS grab the ball before the teammate can. TYRONE'S han The GAME stops dead. Tyrone holds the ball, eyeing the pl with contempt. At his side stands LITTLE BOBBY (16) hyper childlike.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: Tell me, don't you fine black men got anything better to do than play games?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Sure I do, but your sister's busy. Gimme the damn ball. Tyrone passes the ball HARD to Rose.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: Here... Take it. I thought some righteous brothers like you might help us out, but I guess that ain't you...

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: (stepping forward) Help who? With what?

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: Your community! That's who. Maybe  you didn't know but a kid died today.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BOBBY
dialogues.text: That's three this year... same spot.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: Damn straight. And old Reverend Slocum's having a vigil on that corner, trying to get a stoplight put in.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (to Cy) My Mom's at that.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Funny you don't look like church folk to me.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: Oh I ain't. But it seems The Man's getting uptight about black folk standing in the street, causing a fuss. What I'm asking for, is some of your able black asses to come down and be "Observers" on the cops. Take down badge numbers. They don't like pulling shit with too many eyes on tem. So that's how you can help, not by praying but by watching.

dialogues.speaker: DRINKER
dialogues.text: Not me. This able black ass ain't fucking with no cops. Others MUMBLE in agreement, moving away from Tyrone.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Look, I understand but if some Blacks insist on trying to interact with the white man, that's not our concern. We are African, "brother." Mother Africa is the only... Anger FLASHES in Tyrone's eyes. His voice turn knifelike.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: No, you look, you phony ass boojie nigger. We ain't in Africa, we're in Oakland. And in Oakland we got police brutality. We got the white man interacting his billy club up against the black man's head. Now if that don't bother you, then take your skirt wearing ass back to Africa... "Uncle." Jamal -- very angry -- takes a step toward Tyrone. Tyron backs him down with one fearsome look.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE,
dialogues.text: Try it. Jamal backs away, joining Rose and the exiting drinkers.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BOBBY
dialogues.text: (watching them go) Chickenshit boojie...

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: (to Judge and Cy) What about you two? You were there, you saw that kid?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I saw... but...

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: But nothing... you do live here don't you? Judge glares evenly back at Tyrone, sizing him up.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: (to Judge and Cy) Well, act like it. Come on. Tyrone and Little Bobby leave the court. After a beat, Ju and Cy follow. ROSE calls after them, BAITING.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: You young niggas crazy. The Man ain't gonna let us have no say in running shit! Keep it up and he's gonna come down on our ass like a ton of bricks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking confident strides, Tyrone and Little Bobby lead Cy and Judge down the street.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: Don't let the cops provoke you. We're there to watch and take badge numbers...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: And who is we?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BOBBY
dialogues.text: Brother where you been? (a smile) We're the Black Panthers. Cy and Judge register the name. cy The Panthers... (to Bobby) How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BOBBY
dialogues.text: Sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Shit, we made him get his moms to give permission before he could sign up.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Just a kid.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, cops kick the shit out of kids too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CIRCLE of church folk hold flickering CANDLES in the mi of the intersection. Slocum's there as well as RITA. Thei faces are silent, passive in the candlelight. POLICE CARS can be seen parked at the curbs. A small CADR of cops stands watching the congregation. Tyrone, Judge and Cy approach the vigil. Looking around, they spot other YOUNG BLACK MEN staked out at the four co of the intersection.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I thought you said all the Panthers were gonna be here.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: What you see is what you got. (pointing) That's' Bobby Seale. Judge's eyes pick BOBBY out, skinny, notebook at the read

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: Carter... buddy of mine from way back... And Gene... CARTER -- enormous, terrifying -- comes into view, then G  a wiry street tough.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BOBBY
dialogues.text: And that... that's Huey... Judge strains to focus on HUEY NEWTON -- who's just a SILHOUETTE against a streetlight. There's a BOOK in his r hand and an aura of power surrounding him. cy Ain't too many of you is there?

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: (a slight smile) Only takes a single grain of sand to move the world...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BOBBY
dialogues.text: (spotting something) Heads up!!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PATROL CAR floats to a quick stop at the curb. White ha red-faced, SERGEANT SCHRECK bounds from the car.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. SCHRECK
dialogues.text: What in the Sam Hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: A vigil for some pickaninny got hit here.

dialogues.speaker: SGT. SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Vigil my ass... Schreck GRABS a BULLHORN from the car.

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: (through the bullhorn) Listen up, you all have 30 seconds to disperse and return to your homes. The LINE OF COPS takes a small step toward the black folk

dialogues.speaker: SCHRECK
dialogues.text: Failure to do so will result in your immediate arrest... The churchgoers flail a bit. Suddenly, with HUEY in the background, SLOCUM steps up and with a look of defiant pi begins SINGING "We Shall Not Be Moved." With gathering force the CONGREGATION joins in the song. Schreck ROLLS HIS EYES and makes a MOTION with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COPS wade into the crowd, herding them away. A patrolman pushes a MIDDLE AGED MAN, with his NIGHTSTICK.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: Go on get your black hide outta here... The MAN STUMBLES. By reflex, the cop RAISES his nightstic TYRONE -- on instinct -- PUSHES the cop away. CHAOS erupts. BILLY CLUBS snap up. Terrified, the congreg RUNS.

dialogues.speaker: BULLEORN
dialogues.text: You are resisting arrest!... Police slap and snatch Black folks right and left. Judge bounces around in the confusion. Bobby Seale can be seen trying to get badge numbers. Judge's eyes widen as he sees RITA running toward an alle a COP right on her ass.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Oh shit Mom... Judge runs toward her. The cop lifts his BILLY CLUB over Rita... Boom!! Carter PUNCHES the cop straight off his feet. A PAIR OF COPS have thrown Tyrone down on the ground -- PISTOLS pressed against his head. Judge moves to Tyrone's aid. A RIFLE BUTT flashes out, cracking across Judge's temple, sending him into DARKNESS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge slowly comes to on the filthy floor. Cy, a few nast bruises on his face, kneels next to him protectively.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (amazed, in pain) Jesus... Disoriented, Judge sees TYRONE and the other PANTHERS. Th a rag tag little group, battered, locked down. SLOCUM'S t too. Coming fully awake, Judge realizes SOMEONE is speaking. I HUEY, his voice powerful and arresting in its urgency.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: (over)  The power structure locks the black man up. That's right. We move from chains to bars and locks. Kangaroo courts put brothers in jail. No jury of our peers. No jury of black folks. How do we stop this insanity? It's simple. Organization. That's the key. We must organize. We must maintain discipline

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge peers through the bodies and sees HUEY.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: That's right brother... listen and learn.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: The white power structure wants us to act like savages. (a smile) But we're a different kind of animal altogether. We're Panthers. And The Black Panther Party for Self Defense is very painfully aware that America has historically reserved its most barbaric treatment for non-white people since the beginning of the country. So we need to organize, we (a charismatic smile) keep our shit correct! And effect revolution. We revolve the power into the hands of the people. Where it belongs. (a beat) Power to the people baby...

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Power? Shit, old folks can't even sing without getting their asses kicked.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Well, then like the man said... Maybe it's time we stop singing and start swinging.

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: Yeah, but they got the guns. Something -- some inexplicable mixture of mirth, raw intelligence and fierce willpower -- crosses Huey's face.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: We can change that. We got the right to bear arms, so I'd say it's time to exercise that right. Like Comrade Mao says, "Justice through power,  Power through guns."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blinking in the sunlight, the Panthers descend wearing a collective grin of relief.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: Chickenshits, just harassing our ass, we weren't breaking any law.

dialogues.speaker: REV. SLOCUM
dialogues.text: But at least we're free! God has delivered us from the lion's den.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Free? We're back where we started. Shit we still don't have a stop light.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Well as the Rev says, God helps those who help themselves. (a smile) We'll be our own stoplight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huey marches into the middle of the street. Amid swerving cars and screeching brakes he begins DIRECTING TRAFFIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge and Cy split off as the other Panthers march into t intersection, joining Huey's traffic duty. cy (pointing) Check it out... Great huh? I tell you those guys know what time it is. Man I'm with that...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I don't know. Look around man. cy C'mon Judge we got to start somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, and I'm gonna start by getting on my feet. Working on things from inside the system. cy Inside ain't in the system. (poking Judge) It's right there inside you!! I'm joining up.  Judge's face cracks into a wry SMILE. Suddenly his smile fades when he spots RITA staring at him from her stoop.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I... I gotta go... Judge crosses the street, heading over to his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concern searing her face, Rita regards her son warily.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: It's okay Mom. I'm allright.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You don't look alright.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (touching his head) Yeah... cop hit me...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I saw. I saw that big one (pointing to Carter) hit that police man. Saw 'em drag you off too. (a beat) They take you to jail?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (soft) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Lord, never thought I'd live to see my boy in prison.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Mom! It wasn't like that. It was bullsh... They were just harassing us. No charges were filed. It's alright. Worry in her voice, Rita stares across at the Panthers.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You meet those friends of yours in jail too?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Yes... No... Mom it's not like you think. They're alright. There out there trying to do something.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I hear them boys, those Black Panthers, they're communists. They don't even believe in God.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Mom, black folks been praying to God for four hundred years. Maybe it's time we tried something else...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You believe that?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I don't know. I really don't. A moment passes, Rita notes her son's confusion.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I'll tell you one thing Judge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Following Huey's lead, the Panthers move traffic through intersection. CY'S with them, guiding cars past.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (over) Them boys gonna start a bunch of trouble they keep on like that.

dialogues.speaker: INT. OAKLAND POLICE HEADQUARTERS- DAY
dialogues.text: DORSETT, the Chief Duty Officer, shifts behind his desk, popping a TUMS. A VOICE comes from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: RODGERS
dialogues.text: (over) Those things don't work... Looking up, Dorsett sees RODGERS -- a hawk-faced guy with slippery glasses. He's FBI down to the shine on his shoes

dialogues.speaker: DORSETT
dialogues.text: Don't I know it. Come on in Agent Rodgers. Sit down. Always a... pleasure to see you. How can I be of help?

dialogues.speaker: RODGERS
dialogues.text: It's a bit more like how can we help you. Bay Area's become quite a hornet's nest in terms of subversive activities. And... well Mr. Hoover wants to reiterate that the FBI will be happy to assist local authorities in any way we can. On a strictly advisory basis... of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Well, I appreciate your offer, but we got things pretty well under control. Same bunch of kooks you guys already have under surveillance. They're still doing a lot of yelling and pot-smoking but nothing to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: RODGERS
dialogues.text: (cocking an eyebrow) I see. What about the Black Panther Party for Self-Defense?

dialogues.speaker: DORSETT
dialogues.text: Heh, bunch of shines running around in dark caps waving their fists about some streetlight. They're loud, but they aren't dangerous,

dialogues.speaker: RODGERS
dialogues.text: Can you make a deal with them?

dialogues.speaker: DORSETT
dialogues.text: Naw... They're kids mostly. Idealists. They actually think they're for real.

dialogues.speaker: RODGERS
dialogues.text: Hmmm. As you know the Bureau -- and Mr. Hoover -- is particularly "sensitive" to anything that might agitate or solidify the coloreds on the left. Dorsett pauses for a second, trying to read the angle.

dialogues.speaker: DORSETT
dialogues.text: You want me to put a man on it?

dialogues.speaker: RODGERS
dialogues.text: That would be an excellent start. (a pause) Tell him to keep a low profile.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FIFTY FIFTH AND MARKET
dialogues.text: Panthers direct traffic at the corner. On the other side the street a VW BUS with a UC BERKELEY sticker sits. SABU's talking to a WHITE HIPPIE in the bus.

dialogues.speaker: SABU
dialogues.text: What do you want? Panama Red? I can get you Panama Red Sinsemilla? Got a line on some chocolate hash... get you high as a motherfucking monkey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhh... man I was wondering... (dropping his voice) can you get some Cocaine?

dialogues.speaker: SABU
dialogues.text: Coke? Shee-it. (dropping his voice) Yeah, I can get you cocaine. But it's dangerous. Cops everywhere. Gimme twenty dollars and meet me back here in an hour. And don't fuck around white boy, this is the serious shit.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE HIPPIE
dialogues.text: Uh okay, alright. You'll be here in an hour?

dialogues.speaker: SABU
dialogues.text: Yeah I'll be here. Sabu grabs a TWENTY from the van. He SMILES as the van pu away.

dialogues.speaker: SABU
dialogues.text: (to himself) Now that was one dumb motherfucker... cy, Tyrone at his side, APPEARS. cy Sabu, what the fuck you doing? Ain't nobody gonna push on this street.

dialogues.speaker: SABU
dialogues.text: Shit, I ain't doing nothing. White bread asks for cocaine, I take his money. Shit... you know... It was just a hustle. cy Sabu... High white dude's the only thing you could hustle.

dialogues.speaker: SABU
dialogues.text: Man... fuck you. Why you always bustin’ my balls? All that high and mighty militant shit. I ain't doing nothing.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: I dig, you just hustling. But you make sure it stays like that brother, or you will have much grief on your sorry ass.  Cy lets Sabu go. He scrambles down the street.

dialogues.speaker: SABU
dialogues.text: (to himself) Motherfucking Panthers, worse than the police...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nestled among empty paper COFFEE CUPS, BRIMMER - a once athletic white cop -- watches the Panthers at the corner. stubs yet another CIGARETTE into an overflowing ashtray. Brimmer sees CY taking over traffic duty from CARTER. The a NOTEPAD on the seat next to Brimmer. He makes a HASH MA in it -- COUNTING Panther heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bottle of BITTER DOG in hand, Rose sits with the other drinkers, STARING at Brimmer's car. Taking a swig and smi at his buddies, Rose walks toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sauntering up to the car, Rose flashes a wicked grin.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: What's the matter Casper, you lost or something? Brimmer IGNORES him.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Hey! I'm talking to you. Rolling his eyes, BRIMMER holds up his BADGE. A gold DETECTIVE'S shield gleams at Rose through the glass.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Ohhhh... Looky there... (to the other drinkers) It's a Cop... Behind him the other drinkers RISE, checking Brimmer out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brimmer fumes, so much for keeping a low profile.

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: Fuck. The Detective STARTS his car.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FIFTY FIFTH AND MARKET
dialogues.text: Rose and the others goofing at him, Brimmer PULLS AWAY f the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIMMER'S CAR glides by the storefront.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HUEY talks earnestly with TYRONE and GENE.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: ...Yeah, it's a perfect next step, let the community know that we're dedicated to Malcolm's ideals... (checking his watch) Damn where's Bobby Seale? BOBBY SEALE, a whirlwind of energy, come careening throug the door.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY SEALE
dialogues.text: Huey!! Man you gotta check this out... You're gonna love...

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Hold up a second... We got a decision to make.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY SEALE
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Dig it, you know those brothers over in San Fran... call themselves the Black Panthers too?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY SEALE
dialogues.text: Sure, those boojie jokers don't do anything except print up a lotta paper saying "Black is Beautiful."

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE,
dialogues.text: Shit, nothing but Paper Panthers.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: (a smile) Yeah... but it seems they're bringing Malcolm's widow Betty Shabazz to town, to speak at a rally, do an interview for Ramparts. (a pause) And they want us to help with security.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well if anyone's gonna protect Malcolm's legacy it better be us.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Damn straight... (rising) Let's go check out these Paper Panthers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY'S PONTIAC sits in front of a rather upscale house, a street that would never be mistaken for Oakland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking street and very tough, BOBBY, HUEY, TYRONE, LITTL BOBBY and GENE walk in. Spotting them, ROY -- the Paper Panther President -- picks his afro and smoothes his DASH vainly. In the background other men in AFRICAN GARB can be seen, along with ALMA - a REGAL BLACK GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Greetings African brothers... You're here to help us with Sister Shabazz no doubt?

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Fucking boojie...

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: That's right. We'd be proud to provide as escort for Malcolm's widow. How many men you got?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (to Alma) Get the brothers a beer. Me too while you're at it. (to Huey) Men? Well we can spare six for security...

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: (to Alma, declining the beer) No thank you sister. (to Roy) Six?!! That seems a little light. Cops are watching Betty, watching her hard. We need at least twenty  men. And that's twenty armed Panthers dig? You do have guns don't you?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I assure you that we as the revolutionary vanguard are as serious about this as you are. We'll be prepared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disgusted, HUEY stalks to the car with the others.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE,
dialogues.text: They ain't fit for the name Panthers

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Twenty men? I don't know if we got that.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: We'll get them. Right now we got to worry about being armed and ready to protect Betty Shabazz. Those phonies sure as hell can't. We need guns

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: We need money first...

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Yeah... Bobby you gotta...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (moving) Got it covered Huey, that's what I was trying to tell you before. Check it out... Bobby's pops the PONTIAC'S TRUNK. BOXES sit inside it, overflowing with LITTLE RED BOOKS.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Bought every copy in Chinatown. Got us a discount too, thirty cents a piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the stream of students, Tyrone, Huey and THE PANTHERS hold up Mao's LITTLE RED BOOK. A RADIO can be heard blari Gladys Knight's "Heard it through the Grapevine."

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Here it is Brothers. The Lowdown straight from comrade Mao's mouth.  (to Bobby) If you open the minds, the bodies will follow. CARTER moves toward Huey with TWO WHITE STUDENTS

dialogues.speaker: CARTER
dialogues.text: (looking confused) Huey uhhh... these... these guys want to join... Huey smiles and shakes his head congenially.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry boys. But right now The Party feels it's important for Black People to do it for themselves. We're not signing up white folk. (the trademark smile) But, if you are down with what we're doing, organize some righteous white folks. I got a feeling we're gonna need each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge, holding notes and SCHOOLBOOKS spots the Panthers. catches his eye.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Hey, this what they got you doing now? cy Party needs the bread. (to the students) Be hip to the struggle, only a dollar!!!

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: A dollar? Far out! Is it authentic? cy Comrade, this here's the real deal, straight from Revolution HQ.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Huh? (catching on) Hey, I can dig it man. (buying book) Thanks! Long live the revolution, brother. cy (to Judge, pocketing the bills)  Money's cool, but what the party really needs is brothers like you. (hands Judge a RED

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: Judge I could use someone like you. These books, hell I don't know half the words. You might.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Have to pass on the revolution today man, I got class... But how about tonight, I was gonna check out "Cloud Nine." Just like old times. cy Can't... they're having a PE meeting at Headquarters tonight, come on down. Check it out.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: PE? What? You guys doing gym class? cy No man. PE -- "political education." TYRONE moves closer to Cy, checking out Judge

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE,
dialogues.text: You're a smart brother... you should dig what Huey and Bobby got to say...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Maybe...

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: (a smile) Fuck maybe... be there. Judge grins back at Tyrone, holding ground.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Like I said... maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Essentially a storefront, the PANTHER HQ's a rag-tag, hip shrine. POSTERS hangs in the window -- "BLACK IS BEAUTIFU the BLACK PANTHER LOGO, an upraised BLACK FIST. CY and JUDGE walk past a couple of loitering street folk. ROSE is there, happily munching on a paper plate of stew.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Rose, what the hell you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Just come for the food, man. Ain't  quite sure what their bag is but... Rose POINTS through the doorway to BOBBY SEALE standing a podium speaking front of a very small GROUP.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: That one's one hell of a cook...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Bobby and Tyrone PASS out LEAFLETS labeled with "W we want" and What we Believe" to a SMALL ASSEMBLY. At the podium, Bobby SPEAKS passionately. Judge and Cy ma for empty secondhand seat.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: ...We... the Black Panther Party are not anarchists. We want a government that serves the people. In the black community we want a government that serves black people. Black cops for Black People. Not the Army we have occupying the community "Army?" you ask. "What army? This isn't Vietnam." Well the Army's right out your door folks. They're the cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chorus of "Yeahs," "Right Ons and APPLAUSE."

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: They're pigs brothers and sisters. And these pigs are soldiers fighting against us. Whether you got an Afro or a process on. Whether a sister's got her hair straightened or whether she's got a natural on. Whether it's a brother in a dashiki or a pimp with a sharp suit on. Whether a sister's prostituting or teaching kids to read. The pig will murder you because you're black. No matter what kind of hair you wear. So we best get ourselves together, organize, learn our history and put the power in the hands of the black community before this army, these pigs wipe this community out. Applause rings out. Even JUDGE claps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Political Education over, the small group of Panthers and neighborhood folk, chat as Judge makes his way over to Cy cy  ...Glad you came man.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, only I figure you'd be the one doing the speaking. cy Not yet, one of these day's maybe. Bobby's party chairman. Political Education's really his bag. Huey steps up with TYRONE.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: You're Cy's Vietnam buddy right? (Judge nods) C'mere I'd like to talk with you... Huey pulls Judge toward a BACK ROOM, Tyrone watches them leave, protective, suspicious...

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: You were. infantry right?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: So I guess it's safe to say you know about firepower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP: A nest of WEAPONS -- shotguns, Ml's, handguns - sit is on a DESK in the cluttered back room of the store. Judge's hands run over the guns, checking them out. He se an AUTOMATIC aside.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Busted firing pin. (checking a revolver) You want only the legal stuff right?

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE,
dialogues.text: Just the legit shit. Judge SETS ASIDE the revolver. MR. YANG -- a nervous oriental man -- hovers over them.

dialogues.speaker: MR. YANG
dialogues.text: Nothing wrong with that pistol.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Serial number's been filed. Cop catches you with that he figures you  either stole it or killed someone with it...

dialogues.speaker: MR. YANG
dialogues.text: I don't want no trouble. No cops coming to me about these guns.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: No trouble here. You got a permit to sell. (handing over cash) We're buying. All perfectly legal.

dialogues.speaker: MR. YANG
dialogues.text: (counting) These are worth a lot more.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY SEALE
dialogues.text: (pointing to a Mao portrait) I thought you were a revolutionary. We can't afford em if you don't cut us some slack. But... you treat us right and we'll be doing a lot of business.

dialogues.speaker: MR. YANG
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cy and Tyrone load the weapons into Cy's VAN. Bobby, Huey and Judge talk.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: We appreciate your help with this.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: So what's the deal?

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: (a smile) Freedom... We're just gonna test some of the words in that law book. Truck loaded, the Panthers make to leave. Huey lingers a with Judge.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Judge... we're doing security for Betty Shabazz's visit next week. I'd like to have someone who knows there way around a pistol there. Someone like you.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are down for protecting Malcolm's widow aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Yeah... let me think about it.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Okay man I ain't going to push. But remember the revolution isn't going to wait for anyone. Come on, we'll give you a lift.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: No man. Gonna walk. Tyrone watches Judge warily as he turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge, feet moving across pavement, walks alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WHITE PROFESSOR nasally drones about ECONOMICS as Judge stares out the window, watching PANTHERS sell RED BOOKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panthers exhorting the community. Chaos slowly turning in organizations, repainting, sickle cell program, and handi out bags of food as BRIMMER watches from his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A COP CRUISER slowly passes Judge as he walks, shining it SPOTLIGHT on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late. Judge studies a TEXT BOOK. Next to it sits MAO RED BOOK. He can't concentrate. Grabbing his jacket, Judg heads out the DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOBBY'S PONTIAC NIGHT
dialogues.text: Huey's DRIVING. Bobby's next to him, a RIFLE on his lap. Tyrone and CY sit in back. They're all in UNIFORM.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: (to Cy) This here's a "Panther Patrol." We  see a brother getting busted. We check it out, make sure the pig don't go beating on the man. Brother gets taken downtown, we post bail, hook ‘em up with a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: We're like policing the police. Huey SPOTS something through the windshield a COP CAR.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: (pulling over) Damn straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO BEEFY COPS have a BLACK MAN up against the wall. Pant Pontiac pulls to the curb. The cops TURN... HUEY -- holding a RIFLE, backed by the other Panthers -- stares solidly at the policeman.

dialogues.speaker: BEEFY COP
dialogues.text: (into radio) Get me some back up... In the BACKGROUND, the man against the wall SCOOTS AWAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking thinking, Judge moves down the street. After a bi RED LIGHTS can be seen on the wall behind him. Judge MOVE quickly toward the lights, SPOTTING something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near Panther HQ, FIGURES move in silhouette against a SQU CAR's HEADLIGHTS. High tension as HUEY and BOBBY SEALE stand next to the be up PONTIAC holding a RIFLE. THE BEEFY COP faces him -- flashlight in one hand, Huey's LICENSE in the other. Cy, Tyrone and other Panthers -- in full PANTHER UNIFORMS move through the crowd passing out BLACK PANTHER PARTY TE POINT PROGRAMS.

dialogues.speaker: BEEFY COP
dialogues.text: Okay now, er, Huey, so what's your telephone number?

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: I have confirmed to you my address, that's all I'm required to by law to do. We have broken no law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing with the gun?

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: (calm, controlled) What are doing with yours?. As JUDGE pushes through the semi-circle of black folks, T MORE SQUAD CARS pull up. The cops inside swagger over. On of them a BABY FACED COP, has his NIGHT STICK drawn.

dialogues.speaker: BABY FACED COP
dialogues.text: These boys giving you trouble? Beefy Cop shines his light on the PASSENGER SEAT of the Pontiac. It illuminates a PISTOL.

dialogues.speaker: BEEFY COP
dialogues.text: Here's another one. That your pistol there? Bobby Seale reaches over and PICKS UP the pistol. The Pan snap to a STRAIGHT LINE behind Huey.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No! It is not his weapon. A handgun would be a violation of his probation. It's mine! Nearby, THE CLOUD NINE NIGHTCLUB pulses with MUSIC. Purpl suited hipsters move onto the sidewalk observing the escalating scene between Panthers and police.

dialogues.speaker: BEEFY COP
dialogues.text: (stretching out his hand) Lemme see that rifle son...

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: (snatching the gun away) No! This is my private property. According to California law we have a constitutional right to bear arms.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK VOICE IN CROWD
dialogues.text: Them's some badass niggers...

dialogues.speaker: COP 2
dialogues.text: (to the crowd) Okay. Okay. Move along. Go on about your business... Reluctant but docile, the crowd begins to DISPERSE.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Wait!! Brothers! Sisters!! You don't  have to go anywhere. This is your business. Stay right here. The law says as long as you keep a reasonable distance, eight to ten feet to be exact, you've got a right to observe the police carrying out their duties. From what I can see, you're standing some 22 feet away from this man here. So brothers ain't no law being broken. Emboldened by Huey's words, the crowd REGROUPS.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK VOICE IN CROWD
dialogues.text: Talk that good shit Brother...

dialogues.speaker: BEEFY COP
dialogues.text: Is that gun loaded BOY?!! The crowd GASPS, then goes silent as Huey steps right up into the cop's face.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Fish and Game laws clearly state that it is unlawful to have a live round of ammunition in the chamber of a shotgun or rifle in a vehicle...

dialogues.speaker: BLACK VOICE IN CROWD
dialogues.text: Oh sweet Jesus, I do believe I have died and gone to heaven...

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Refer to him as officer.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Well then don't refer to him as BOY!

dialogues.speaker: BEEFY COP
dialogues.text: (glaring) Well... is it loaded?

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: I tell you "officer", it wasn't... Huey COCKS A ROUND into the chamber.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: ...but now IT Is! The cops TENSE. The Beefy One blows a gasket.

dialogues.speaker: BEEFY COP
dialogues.text: For the last time Boy!!! What do those guns mean                        !

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: They mean, Pig!, that the Black Panther Party declares that if you try to brutalize our community or take our weapons. (a beat) We are going to shoot you!!! The crowd stands FROZEN. Joy spreads out beneath their gu ghetto masks.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK VOICE IN CROWD
dialogues.text: (whirling like a dervish) Pigs that's just what the hell they are!!! Cops and Panthers stand TOE TO TOE. Deadly moments pass. eyes flash from Panthers to Crowd. Then something TURNS. cops BACK OFF, climbing into their cars.

dialogues.speaker: GROVE STREET
dialogues.text: Judge moves away, walking down the street. He senses the and amazement of the community, picking up on SNATCHES OF CONVERSATION from a dozen different doorways.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (over) Never thought I'd live to see the day! You know the police ain't nothing but the KKK with badges. A breeze wafts a TEN POINT PROGRAM past Judge. Slowly, thoughtfully he picks the leaflet up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP: A TEN POINT PROGRAM sits in Dorsett's fleshy fingers. It's after hours as Dorsett, Rodgers and BRIMMER - each holding PAMPHLETS -- have a tense "discussion".

dialogues.speaker: DORSETT
dialogues.text: One: "We want freedom. We want the power to determine the destiny of our Black Community." Two: "We want full employment for our people." Three: "We want to end the robbery by the white man of our Black Community." Christ, they're asking for reparations...

dialogues.speaker: RODGERS
dialogues.text: They couldn't have thought this up for themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Yeah... Sounds like the Constitution to me. With a little of the Bill of Rights thrown in...

dialogues.speaker: RODGERS
dialogues.text: Inspector Brimmer, this is no joke During your surveillance have you seen any outside agitators? Professorial types? Communists?

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: No. I've seen Black men handing out bags of food. Having meetings. Patrolling the neighborhood. Having more meetings. They ain't...

dialogues.speaker: RODGERS
dialogues.text: They are carrying guns. They are threatening police officers. They are undermining the United States of America. And you Inspector Brimmer are not taking your duties seriously...

dialogues.speaker: DORSETT
dialogues.text: Now hold on Rodgers...

dialogues.speaker: RODGERS
dialogues.text: Chief Dorsett, if the Black Panthers are going to remain in your jurisdiction, some fundamental changes in attitude need to be made...

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: Like?

dialogues.speaker: RODGERS
dialogues.text: Like, you Inspector Brimmer are not going to be sitting in your car anymore. I think it's time for a more active type of involvement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat by late hours, DORSETT walks to his car -- a brand n CADILLAC, sitting in his 'reserved' spot. A LIMOUSINE pulls up next to him. Its window rolls down. first we don't see the passenger's face.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Evening Chief. Another hard day keeping the streets safe?

dialogues.speaker: DORSETT
dialogues.text: (forced joviality) What are you doing out so late?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: I like to keep an eye on my "investments" so to speak. You know we still need to discuss that business expansion we spoke of.

dialogues.speaker: DORSETT
dialogues.text: (ill at ease) Look, I don't think... LOUIS TRAFFICANTE -- all style, all mobster -- LEANS out window. His right hand man, TONY, at the wheel. He points the Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: TRAFFICANTE
dialogues.text: That's a beautiful car. You'd do well to remember who paid for it. Good night, Chief, we'll speak again soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn pushes pink against the loft windows as Judge, dress for class, pores over Cy's copy of “Wretched of the Earth cy (coming out) Man, did you see Huey down on Grove street? All up on that cop, that was beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it was alright. Hey, can you give me a lift? cy You got it. Berkeley?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: No, Panther Headquarters. (a smile) Least that way we could hang out more like we used to. cy You joining? My Brother.. (hugging Judge) My brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panther HQ has improved. Bobby Seale stands behind a newl painted display counter, interviewing NEW RECRUITS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FACES -- all of them BLACK, all of them MEN, most of them ANGRY -- flash into the frame, each talking.

dialogues.speaker: FACE
dialogues.text: Sign me up!! Just gimme a gun and point out the cops you want me to shoot...

dialogues.speaker: FACE
dialogues.text: Where's the free food at?

dialogues.speaker: FACE
dialogues.text: My momma, she marched with King. Don't know exactly what kinda change that brought. But man you put that cop on Grove through some serious changes!!!

dialogues.speaker: FACE
dialogues.text: I hear you Panther boys get the finest pussy.

dialogues.speaker: FACE
dialogues.text: Vietnam man... I go there and then come back to some honky motherfucker telling me what to do, beating my ass if I don't. Man... fuck that. A FINAL FACE comes into view... JUDGE'S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CY stands proudly next to Judge in front of Bobby. cy Judge is gonna join us. Tyrone looks less than pleased at the news.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Welcome Brother, if we stand together we can break the chains.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: (miffed, to Judge) Huey wants to see you.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: He had a feeling you'd be coming by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge moves warily into the dim and musty room. As his ey acclimate to the gloom he spots HUEY sitting half hidden the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Welcome brother, have you decided to get down with us?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I'm down,

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Yeah... You were a lot of help with those guns. Your soldier shit is bad- ass.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I'd hoped I was finished with all that. But... (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: You know, you're lucky to be back. Most niggers die on the front lines. Seems like that's what they're there for.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Don't I know it. Every brother I knew in "Nam's dead. My company... a land mine. Twenty of my friends dead in less than a second.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Mind if I ask you something? Why'd you put up with shit like that for someone else's war? Judge flashes Huey a look of bare honesty.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Hey, GI bill pays for school. And shit, if I stuck around here, instead of signing up, I'd probably be in jail, or sitting on the stoop drinking Bitter Dog with Rose, you know?

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Yeah I know. You're smart Judge. You ain't no bourgeois nigger like those Paper Panthers across the bay. I need every good man to help us with the security on Betty Shabazz, particularly soldiers. You do solid on that I might have something else  for you, something real important.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Whatever you need, I'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Right on Brother Judge... Huey and Judge grip HANDS.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: With tight precision, HUEY, TYRONE, JUDGE, CY, GENE, BOBB CARTER and LITTLE BOBBY form a circle around BETTY SHABAZ guiding her past AIRPORT POLICE to a waiting car. Led by ROY the PAPER PANTHERS seem useless in their dashi and fluffed Afros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In an INNER OFFICE, Betty Shabazz talks with ELDRIDGE, a tall man wearing sunglasses. In the OUTER OFFICE, Huey's PANTHERS stand by while ROY'S PAPER PANTHERS do little.

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE
dialogues.text: What would you tell young brothers and sisters to do in following Brother Malcolm's footsteps?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY SHABAZZ
dialogues.text: I'd say that Malcolm lives in each of us. We all need to work together for the community. (gesturing outside) Like those brothers out there are... Overhearing, Roy PREENS a bit at Betty's words. Nearby JU flicks his eyes to the GUN at Roy's waistband.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (low) Huey... Suddenly ROY spots something outside... POLICE CARS, foll closely by NEWS VANS.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (nervous) Oh oh... Snapping up his SHOTGUN, Huey nods to the others. Bobby S pulls back his jacket revealing a .45. Solemn, professional, Huey and the Panthers file out the  door. ROY'S PAPER PANTHERS hang behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Led by Huey, the Panthers take up a line between the cops and the office. REPORTERS, expecting another GROVE STREET push forward.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: (eyeing Huey's gun) What's going on here son?

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: We are breaking no law, you've have no right to detain us. A REPORTER spots BETTY SHABAZZ, flanked by JUDGE and TYRO leaving the building heading toward a car.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: There she is!!! Surging forward the reporters PUSH CAMERAS toward BETTY SHABAZZ. One of them, CHUCK, tries to push HUEY away. Controlled, Huey holds Chuck in check, watching Betty mov toward the car. Chuck PUSHES FORWARD trying to get a PICT Seeing Betty safely inside and the car PULLING AWAY, Huey SHOVES Chuck back. Chuck makes to swing at Huey. Huey SHO HIM DOWN.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: (to Cop #1) Arrest this man!!!

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: If I'm gonna arrest anyone it's going to be you... Fast, the PANTHERS take up position behind Huey, their GU highly visible. Huey flicks the SAFETY of his shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Not today! ! ROY come running out, UNARMED, scared yelling at Huey.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Don't point that gun!!!

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: That's right be a smart nigger like your friend. TENSION ripples through the air as ROY runs back inside. Huey glares at the cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not my friend and I promise you pig. Your men draw and this will be a blood bath. It's your call. EVERY PANTHER stands facing the cops, weapons at the read THROUGH the glass PAPER PANTHERS can be seen HIDING. Slowly the cops begin backing away.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: (to the cops) Aren't you going to do anything...

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: (nervous) Like he said asshole, they're not breaking any law... Screeching their TIRES the police leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packed in the car, Bobby, Little Bobby, Judge, Cy and Tyr recount the day as HUEY drives.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BOBBY
dialogues.text: You see that on jive dashiki man, hiding under the desk. Shit paper panthers. Huey notices JUDGE'S SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: What it be Judge. Nobody got hurt, Sister Betty's safe. This was a good day...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: They were empty...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What was empty?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: The Paper Panthers' guns, they weren't loaded. I know guns man. Those guns were empty. Huey's KNUCKLES TIGHTEN on the steering wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FISH fries on a grill as ROY and the PAPER PANTHERS celeb  Alma's looking DISGUSTED with the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Like I say Brothers we are the vanguard. (to Alma) Get me a beer... I tell you once Cleaver's story comes out, we're gonna

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROY'S face DROPS as HUEY AND THE OTHER PANTHERS appear at the edge of the party. Huey marches up, YANKING Roy's gun from his pants, checking it.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: We put our lives on the line today. Malcolm X's widow was on the line today. And your guns weren't even loaded.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: A gun's a gun man. It don't need to be loaded.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Tell that to the pigs. Better yet tell that to Malcolm.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Wait a second there brother...

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: No you wait a second. You and your "Panthers" got three choices. One you join with us and follow our rules. Two you change your name. (a smile) Or three you face annihilation. PAPER PANTHERS step up, Huey's men follow suit. Judge sta right at Huey's.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Pretty boy, you're a long way from Oakland. Fuck you. Bam! Huey hits Roy with a ferocious hook. A BIG PAPER PAN moves on Huey, Judge DROPS HIM like a stone. In seconds Huey's men have kicked the shit out of the Pap Panthers. Huey's got ROY'S FACE in the grill.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: You're exactly the kind of brother we don't need. Kind of brother who gets others killed. Now you gonna change your name. Huey pulls Roy up, his SINGED BEARD covered with fish an onions. ROY just glares silently.

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: Roy, tell him you'll do it. Huey shoves Roy's face back down toward the grill.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Please!!! Yes!!! We'll change the name. Throwing ROY away, Huey LOCKS EYES with Alma as the Panth depart. She watches them every step of the way. Nearby SOMEONE ELSE watches the Panthers also. ELDRIDGE CLEAVER, the reporter from Ramparts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unwinding, alone with Judge, Huey hands him a beer.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: You were alright Judge, better than alright. You're what the Party needs. A fighter but also one that's going to school not making the man too nervous.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I don't know about that.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: I do. You think you're smart enough to keep playing the game?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: What, I don't know how you mean?

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: See, the thing about Panthers. For all their speed and strength. They are not naturally aggressive. They don't just go out killing, tearing through the jungles murdering. No, the Panther (makes a fist) keeps his claws hidden until he is attacked, until he's backed into a corner. Then (opens his fist) believe me those claws are fierce.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Huey, you're losing me. What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about survival. Yours, mine, all of it. Outside and in. You got to do something for me. Staying alive might depend on it. The pigs are gonna try to infiltrate us and we're gonna let 'em. But their spy's gonna be our spy too. How about it? There's a pause as Judge chews on the grave proposition.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Me? You've got a whole lot of other folks signing up. Why me?

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: You fit the profile, Brother. You look exactly like the kind of nigger they think they can trust...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cold harsh building sits like a satisfied giant on the Capitol street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passing a SIGN on the door: FEDERAL BUREAU OF INVESTIGATI DIRECTOR: J.E. HOOVER. The Uber-cop himself sits at the desk, his large watery e scanning a TELETYPE. He presses an INTERCOM.

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: Get me out man in Oakland...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HUGE LINE of NEW RECRUITS stretches outside the buildin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby and Tyrone stand there uncomfortably facing ALMA an platoon of SISTERS.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: Alma!? I uhh I don't think...

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: What do you mean? We're black ain't we? And we care about improving the plight of out people don't we? Or you figure oppression stops at that thing dangling between your legs!

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: (looking to Bobby) Uhh... I with it sister but...

dialogues.speaker: ALMA
dialogues.text: But nothing, we want full fledged membership in the Black Panther Party... and none of this "Okay sugah as long as you stay in the background washing my socks and rubbing my feet" bullshit either! Bobby GRINS.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I can dig that! If your down with the Ten-Point-Program, sign up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panthers place POSTERS of Bobby Seale and Huey in the storefront window as JUDGE, ALMA, CY and TYRONE load LEAF into a VAN.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (over) There's a lot of work to be done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Bobby Hutton lectures a group of school kids

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge's HAND ladles out porridge to a sea of hungry kids. ALMA smiles across the room at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrone and Cy watch as Judge holds an Ml RIFLE, lecturing NEW RECRUITS. Each recruit has a DISASSEMBLED RIFLE. Judg starts his stopwatch. The RECRUITS fumble with the rifles Suddenly a sound -- the perfect clicking and clacking of metal on metal. ALMA assembles her rifle with lightning s Still FUMBLING with their rifles, the other recruits star amazed at Alma. Judge checks the stopwatch... TWENTY SEVE SECONDS. Looking up, Judge and TYRONE'S EYES MEET.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FIFTY FIFTH AND MARKET
dialogues.text: Judge takes his place DIRECTING TRAFFIC. Turning Judge LO EYES with RITA across the street. She looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge hawks RED BOOKS to park goers, engaging them in pr panther banter. Black folk move away from him when they s BRIMMER, an obvious cop, striding toward Judge.

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: You're Judge right? We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I don't know you and I got nothing to say to you.

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: (flashing his badge) Yeah you do. It's up to you either here or downtown. Giving up, Judge walks with Brimmer listening as the cop talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huey's COOKING BREAKFAST for the kids as Alma, Tyrone and Little Bobby serve up bowls of porridge. Passing the munching kids, Judge -- obviously excited -- moves over to Huey.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) They tried to recruit me. Just like you figured. Tyrone looks over,FROWNING. Huey signals him that everyth cool.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: (joking loudly) You're a little old to be a school boy aren't you brother. (whispering) Cool it! You're probably not the only one they've gone after. Stall a little so they believe you're for real. Make them trust you. (raising his voice) Hey Tyrone, you figure feeding our children is gonna make The Man jumpy?

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: (bantering back) Black people getting uppity, feeding their children breakfast, taking their destiny into their own hands. What's this world coming to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pursued, a thin Black man -- DENZIL DOWELL -- LIMPS painf past. TWO COPS, guns drawn, run after him.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Hands up, you ain't going nowhere. Faced with a BLIND ALLEY, Dowell RAISES his hands. The co close in.

dialogues.speaker: DENZIL
dialogues.text: I wasn't going nowhere in the first place. I ain't done shit.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: "Done shit, SIR!!" Nigger don't move... Scared, Denzil instinctively BACKS AWAY from the cops.

dialogues.speaker: DENZIL
dialogues.text: I ain't done... GUNFIRE rips through the alley. CUT To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is filled with mourners. Shades are drawn but a little sun brushes the PANTHERS LEATHER JACKETS. Denzil's brother GEORGE, speaks softly to MOMMA DOWELL.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Momma, these here are the Panthers I asked over from Oakland.

dialogues.speaker: MOMMA DOWELL
dialogues.text: I thank you all for coming to grieve with us. The police won't tell us nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MOURNER
dialogues.text: They been shooting Black men down around here like they're going out of style.

dialogues.speaker: MOMMA DOWELL
dialogues.text: (breaking into tears) My boy didn't do nothing. He didn't do nothing. Can't nobody do something.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: We came to do something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panthers, carrying GUNS, line both sides of the block. NE FACES can be seen with Judge, Alma, Cy, Tyrone, Little Bo and the others. A block or so distant, the SHERIFF'S OFFICE looms up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY SEALE shuttles back and forth distributing PROGRAMS and LEAFLETS to a forest of outstretched Black hands. HUEY stands on top of a car, his strong voice ringing out over the gathering.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: ...The police report says he was shot three times but the coroner's report says quite clearly that Denzil Dowell was shot six times. And two of those shots were in his armpits. Brothers and Sisters you know why that is? (raises his arms up) Because Denzil had his hands up!!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY SEALE
dialogues.text: (to crowd) No more police brutality! WHAT DO WE

dialogues.speaker: JUSTICE
dialogues.text: Frenzied hands grab all the PAMPHLETS from Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: SEALE
dialogues.text: (to Judge) More programs man!!! In the car. Judge moves away toward the PONTIAC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge grabs a pile of LEAFLETS off the seat. Turning back the rally, Judge comes nose to nose with BRIMMER.

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: Afternoon asshole... You shoulda told me about this. C'mon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrone SEES Brimmer spin Judge around and cuff him.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTICE
dialogues.text: Tyrone NUDGES Huey, gesturing to Judge being led to Brimm UNMARKED CAR.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: C'mon let's...

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: No! Just harassment. Can't let it stop this. (an eye to car, then the crowd) Brother we got momentum! Whipped up, the crowd YELLS as Tyrone looks perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What do we want!!??

dialogues.speaker: JUSTICE
dialogues.text: REVEREND SLOCUM steps out, trying to calm the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND SLOCUM
dialogues.text: Amen! The Lord God Almighty be our witness. Let us bow our heads and pray for...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (interrupting, raising his fist)

dialogues.speaker: POWER TO THE PEOPLE
dialogues.text: The Panthers move into precise FORMATION. Huey and Bobby the front, the crowd moves toward the Sheriff's Office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tense, a DOUBLE LINE of police blocks the entrance. With crowd screaming for "JUSTICE!" and "BLACK POWER!" behind them, Bobby and Huey step up to the Deputies.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: (shoving Huey) You're not getting in here with no gun. Huey SHOVES the cop back. The line of cops BRISTLES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This firearm is being carried in plain view and is therefore perfectly legal according to California statute...

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Over my dead body. Huey steps back and Clack!, jerks a ROUND into the gun. A HUSH falls over the crowd. The POLICE raise their weapons

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: That's your call pig. Rev. Slocum puts a steadying hand on Huey's arm.

dialogues.speaker: REV. SLOCUM
dialogues.text: (to cops) We come for justice, not bloodshed but don't be pushing us too far. Tense moments pass. Huey looks over at MOMMA DOWELL, read the concern in her eyes. Then, Huey and Bobby RAISE their weapons up, PASSING THEM the police. Unarmed, The Panthers enter the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrounded by deputies, Bobby and Huey confront the smug SHERIFF.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Bled to death!?!? The Coroner's report says he was shot to death. We demand a grand jury investigation in the death of Denzil Dowell and the pattern of brutality against the Black citizens of Richmond.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: (icy) The Police department has conducted its own inquest and concluded that no misconduct occurred. As for a “pattern of brutality..." The charge is ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Then what do you call four dead Black men in six months?!

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: I call it the police doing there duty under the law. You got a problem with that... take it to the  legislature but get the hell out of my office.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (to Huey) The pig might just have a point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brimmer's UNMARKED CAR sits in front of the tattered buil near the heart of Oakland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDGE -- handcuffed to a chair in the vast lofty space -- looks like he's been through the wringer. BRIMMER, smokin vehemently, hovers over him.

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: So... we understand each other Judge?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (sullen) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RODGERS watches Judge and Brimmer from the SHADOWS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brimmer UNCUFFS Judge from the chair.

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: Alright then. Judge STANDS a little shakily. Brimmer slides a BUSINESS CARD in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: I expect to hear from you soon. If Huey Newton takes a crap, I want to know how big it was. Otherwise I'm gonna come looking for you. And I won't be as "friendly" as today.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I got you. Judge turns to leave. Brimmer stops him

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: You just remember one thing Judge.  You've got a lot at stake. And The Panthers are gonna lose. Question is, are you gonna lose along with them? Your future? Your mother? Think about it. Judge leaves. Brimmer takes a long drag of his cigarette, STARING at RODGERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half a step out the door, Judge THROWS Brimmer's CARD awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A combination BARBECUE/AWARENESS RALLY covers the park Panthers and just plain neighborhood folk eat, drink and talk. Judge - a worried look on his face -- walks by. Huey's on the podium, speaking clearly and passionately.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: As soon as black people exercise their rights to bear arms and defend themselves the pigs want to change the law. We're not going to make it easy for them to have unarmed targets. Now, you all have a good time cause this here's our community and it is a beautiful thing. (raising his fist) Power to the people. Pulsing MUSIC kicks in as Huey steps from the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huey joins a meeting in progress with Tyrone, Alma and Bo who's particularly edgy.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: This brothers is gonna be a colossal event. We'll shut the mother down right at the capitol, in front of the cameras. (annoyed off Bobby's pacing) Will you cool it? What's up man? What it be Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What it be is, You aren't coming with us.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: What? We're the leadership, you and me. There ain't enough of us to...  Admiring,

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: That's just it Huey. The pigs don't know how many Panthers there are. Both of us show and they might start putting 2 and 2 together. We're not

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: even two hundred strong yet... but we got 'em guessing thousands.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: I hear you. Alright. I'll go, you stay. Bobby shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Huey... We took a vote. You're still on probation. We can't risk you. Things is starting to get hot. Go mow yo momma's lawn like you promised. Huey's TENSES, ready to argue. Then he SPOTS Judge. A LOO passes between them.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Alright, I'll stay. Judge, I want to...

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE,
dialogues.text: (to Judge) Where you been? I saw the cops rousting you at the rally.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Aw... uh... it's was just harassment. My driver's license expired.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: Chickenshits, they're grabbing at anything. Huey leads Judge away, Tyrone WATCHES them closely, very suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huey's charged, talking fast to Judge.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: What's the pig's name?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Brimmer.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: (very serious) You got to keep very cool on this.  Icy god damn cool. Cause baby, you just became the strongest weapon we got. Let me guess, he wants you to call him, tell him what we're doing.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: And you're gonna do just that. But I'll tell you what to feed the pig. You alright with this?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Yeah... I guess. Any of other Panthers know about this? Huey just looks at Judge silently.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Man, this shit's pretty thick.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: You got that right. And brother, I got a feeling it's going to get a whole lot thicker.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Governor RONALD REAGAN stands on the Capitol lawn speakin to THE FUTURE LEADERS -- a teenage group. Suddenly, THE PANTHERS pull up, stepping out of their car ARMED, clad in black leather. CHAOS erupts. Bodyguards whisk Reagan away as a swarm of NEWS CREWS con on the Panthers. CAMERAS flanked around him, a REPORTER s a microphone in Bobby's face.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSMAN
dialogues.text: Is this a militant action? Are the Panthers storming the Capitol?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No!!! Definitely not!!! (to the news camera) We are here to send a message. The Black Panther Party for Self Defense calls upon the American people in general and Black people in particular to take careful note of the racist California Legislature now considering the Mulford Act, which is aimed at keeping Black people disarmed and powerless while racist police agencies  throughout the country intensify the terror, brutality, murder and repression of Black people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to tell who there's more of -- Panthers or repo as the chaotic circus enters a LONG CORRIDOR. Seale's in the lead, with Little Bobby, Alma and Tyrone following. Disoriented, they CLIMB stairs, continuing dow another CORRIDOR. A GUARD at a DOORWAY starts to freak.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: You can't come in here!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We are here to observe the Assembly. You will not stop us.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: This door leads to the Assembly floor, it's closed to the public. You have to go to the Visitor's Gallery, it's... The guard TURNS TO POINT, Seale twists to follow his fing Reporters swing around. A crewman BUMPS into the guard. C The entourage PANICS, stumbling through the door. A mass Panthers and reporters spill into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pro Tem Speaker Carlos Bee's mouth drops as a noisy mass Panthers and reporters careens into the chambers. Swiftly the rat pack of reporters BACKS AWAY, leaving the Panthers, armed and confused, in the MIDDLE OF THE ROOM. SECURITY GUARDS converge on the Panthers.

dialogues.speaker: FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: Camera pans up from lawnmower to Huey's face.

dialogues.speaker: FADE INTO
dialogues.text: US and International HEADLINES scream the story. "New Yor Times," France's "Le Figaro, Italy's "Il Giornale." The Panthers have just become a worldwide phenomenon.

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: (over) Tell the court Mr. Seale are you proud to be the co-founder of the Panthers, an anti-white movement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over) The Black Panther Party is not anti- white, you cannot fight racism with racism. APPLAUSE rings out.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (over) Gentlemen, please approach the bench. The Judge's GAVEL BANGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby, Huey, Prosecutors, Defenders and the Judge yell. G still banging, a rapid-fire PLEA BARGAIN is underway.

dialogues.speaker: DEFENSE ATTORNEY
dialogues.text: My clients broke no law. It was an accident, a wrong turn. Besides, the guns were not illegal. Dismissal!

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: They will be as soon as the Mulford act passes. Six Months for everyone! Huey SHAKES his head at the Defense Attorney.

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: Okay, last offer. Ninety days, no felony charges, just a disturbing the peace. Huey NODS.

dialogues.speaker: DEFENSE ATTORNEY
dialogues.text: Deal!

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: Not so fast. But only if he (points to Bobby) and one of his lieutenants agree to six months.

dialogues.speaker: HUEY
dialogues.text: You got six months to donate to the party, Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You know it brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TAPE MACHINE rolls as a very agitated FBI director g into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: RODGERS
dialogues.text: (over) ...at least that takes Bobby Seale off the street...

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: Not good enough Rodgers. Not good enough at all. Black terrorists on the floor of a State Capitol. I will not say this again, these Negro Commies are to be stopped and now. You tear them down. Either from the outside or the inside.

dialogues.speaker: RODGERS
dialogues.text: (over) We're working on that...

dialogues.speaker: HOOVER
dialogues.text: Work harder. And get me some results. Those Black Bastards could be up to anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finished with traffic duty Judge walks home. He passes BRIMMER'S CAR at the curb.

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: C'mon we're going for a ride...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brimmer's car pulls onto the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brimmer lights a cigarette angrily.

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell us about the party you boys were planning at the capitol?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Shit man. It was... you know spontaneous.

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: Spontaneous my ass!! You told the press and you don't tell me. Remember you're working for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... whatever you say.

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: Are you fucking with me? You smartass piece of shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brimmer's car SWERVES pulling over in the MIDDLE of the bridge. Playing angry cop to hilt, Brimmer jumps out.

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: Get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: What's with you?

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: Get out of the fucking car. Judge obeys. Brimmer produces HANDCUFFS. He CUFFS Judge.

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: "Whatever you say, Inspector Brimmer." Fucking a right pal. Time you got your wiry head on straight. Brimmer grabs the front of Judge's shirt, PUSHING him har against the railing. It's a hellish drop. Brimmer pushes harder. Judge's FEET scramble for purchase.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: What are you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: Do you know how easy it would be for you to just disappear. Shit, you wouldn't even wash up for weeks. Do you fucking understand? (still pushing) I want you to move your ass outta neutral. I want a bunch of Panthers served up on a fucking plate. I want you to set 'em up... armed robbery!!

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I can't... they don't operate that way...

dialogues.speaker: BRIMMER
dialogues.text: Fuck how they operate. Just do it. like your man says, "By any means necessary." Brimmer UNCUFFS Judge, stuffing an ENVELOPE OF MONEY in h pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright then. Here's a little help on your tuition. Get back in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In UNIFORM, proud -- Tyrone and Cy walk down the street t Cy and Judge's APARTMENT.

dialogues.speaker: TYRONE
dialogues.text: Where the hell's Judge anyway? cy Between school and the Panthers, he's been running raw. I never see... Aw shit... Cy catches SOMETHING happening across the street.
